question: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents to her physician with flu-like symptoms for the past 3 days. She has a runny nose, mild headache, and feels achy. She has a mild fever and diffuse rash over her body. She is concerned about the health of her baby and wants to know if there are any medications that will make her feel better in a short time. Currently, she is at her 29th week of gestation and has received the tetanus vaccination as part of the antenatal care program she received since she immigrated at the end of her first trimester from Romania. She is otherwise healthy. Considering this patient, she is at a higher risk of giving birth to a newborn who will present with which of the following options?
model_answer: I don't know the answer.

question: A 54-year-old man presents with the acute onset of seizures and hallucinations. The patient’s wife says that he had been on a camping trip a few months earlier to study bats but otherwise has not traveled recently. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, managed medically with hydralazine and enalapril. The patient’s condition rapidly deteriorates, and he passes away. An autopsy is performed and a histologic stained section of the brain is shown in the image. Which of the following receptors are targeted by the pathogen most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
model_answer: I don't know.

question: A 51-year-old Asian woman presents to her primary care provider with abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rebound tenderness in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen. Further workup suggests ovarian cancer, which is confirmed later in the week to be stage 4 with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain. Which of the following routes describes the most likely lymphatic route for this malignancy to have metastasized to the brain?

options.A: Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
options.B: Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
options.C: Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
options.D: Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
options.E: Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation

model_answer:
The lymphatic system is a network of tissues and organs that help rid the body of toxins, waste and other unwanted materials. The primary function of the lymphatic system is to transport lymph, a fluid containing infection-fighting white blood cells, throughout the body. In the context provided, the ovarian cancer has metastasized to the brain via the lymphatic system. The most likely route for this would be from the sentinel node (the first lymph node to which cancer cells are most likely to spread from a primary tumor) to the right or left lumbar trunk, then to the cisterna chyli (a dilated sac at the lower end of the thoracic duct into which lymph from the intestinal trunk and two lumbar lymphatic trunks flow), then to the thoracic duct (the main vessel of the lymphatic system, running up through the body and emptying into the left subclavian vein), and finally into the systemic circulation.

Final Answer: B. Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation

question: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment three days after being prescribed a selective alpha-1 agonist. He reports improvement in his symptoms and has not experienced any adverse effects. This drug was most likely prescribed for which of the following conditions?

options.B: Bilateral hand tremors of indeterminate etiology
options.C: Urinary hesitancy due to benign prostatic hyperplasia
options.D: Nasal congestion due to a viral infection
options.E: Blood pressure management prior to pheochromocytoma excision

model_answer:
The context mentions that alpha-adrenergic blockers are effective in treating lower urinary tract symptoms in men with prostatic hypertrophy. This suggests that a selective alpha-1 agonist, which would have the opposite effect of a blocker, would not be used for this condition. Therefore, option C is unlikely. The context also mentions that alpha-blockers are used in the management of patients with pheochromocytoma, which suggests that an alpha-agonist would not be used for this condition, making option E unlikely. Alpha-1 agonists are typically used to constrict blood vessels in the nasal passages, which can help relieve nasal congestion. Therefore, option D seems the most likely.

Final Answer: D.

question: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic glomerulonephritis due to IgA nephropathy presents to your office with bone pain. Which of the following laboratory findings would you most expect upon analysis of this patient's serum?

options.A: Increased PTH, decreased calcium, increased phosphate, decreased calcitriol
options.B: Decreased PTH, increased calcium, increased phosphate, increased calcitriol
options.C: Increased PTH, increased calcium, decreased phosphate, decreased calcitriol
options.D: Decreased PTH, decreased calcium, increased phosphate, decreased calcitriol
options.E: Normal PTH, normal calcium, normal phosphate, normal calcitriol

model_answer:
The patient's history of chronic glomerulonephritis due to IgA nephropathy suggests chronic kidney disease (CKD). In CKD, the kidneys are unable to properly excrete phosphate, leading to hyperphosphatemia. This, in turn, inhibits the conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys, leading to decreased calcitriol levels. Decreased calcitriol and hyperphosphatemia both suppress the absorption of calcium in the gut, leading to hypocalcemia. The parathyroid glands respond to hypocalcemia by increasing the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Therefore, the expected laboratory findings in this patient would be increased PTH, decreased calcium, increased phosphate, and decreased calcitriol.

Final Answer: A. Increased PTH, decreased calcium, increased phosphate, decreased calcitriol

question:
A 50-year-old man visits his physician after 20 years of not seeking any medical care. He is concerned about his health after a colleague recently had a heart attack. The patient has no active complaints and says he feels healthy; however, he does not exercise regularly and lives a sedentary lifestyle. He is employed as an administrative position at a local college, and is seated at a desk most of the day. His father had a heart attack at age 54 and his mother is still alive with no health concerns. He does not smoke, only drinks socially, and does not use drugs. Today, his blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination reveals an obese male with no significant findings. An ECG shows no abnormalities, and laboratory testing shows the following:
Laboratory test
Serum glucose (fasting)  105 mg/dL
Serum electrolytes 
Sodium  142 mEq/L
Potassium 3.9 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Serum creatinine 0.8 mg/dl
Blood urea nitrogen 10 mg/dl
Cholesterol, total 250 mg/dL
HDL-cholesterol 35 mg/dL
LDL-cholesterol 186 mg/dL
Triglycerides 170 mg/dL
Urinalysis 
Glucose  negative
Ketones negative
Leucocytes negative
Nitrites negative 
Red blood cells (RBC) negative 
Casts negative 
Which of the following lab abnormalities in this patient is an indication for treatment?
model_answer:
The patient's blood pressure reading is slightly elevated, but not to a level that would require immediate treatment. His weight is a concern, but it is not a lab abnormality. His triglyceride levels are elevated, but not to a level that would require immediate treatment. His fasting glucose level is slightly elevated, indicating a possible risk for diabetes, but it is not at a level that would require immediate treatment. However, his LDL-cholesterol level is significantly elevated. High levels of LDL-cholesterol can lead to a buildup of cholesterol in the arteries, increasing the risk of heart disease and stroke. Therefore, this would be an indication for treatment.

Final Answer: D.

question:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of an increasing difficulty in hearing over the past several months. His mother says they have to speak at a higher volume for him to understand them. He also complains of having difficulty reading his favorite books because he is not able to see the words clearly. His father received a renal transplant in his 20s. The vital signs are within normal limits. The physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Serum
Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
Urine
Blood 1+
Protein 1+
RBC 15–17/hpf
WBC 1–2/hpf
The audiometry shows bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The ophthalmologic examination shows anterior lenticonus. Which of the following best explains these findings?
model_answer:
The boy's symptoms of hearing loss, visual difficulty, and the presence of blood and protein in his urine, along with the history of his father receiving a renal transplant in his 20s, suggest a genetic disorder affecting the kidneys, eyes, and ears. Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by glomerulonephritis, end-stage kidney disease, and hearing loss. Patients can also have eye abnormalities, including anterior lenticonus, which is the bulging of the lens of the eye, and this is a pathognomonic feature of Alport syndrome. The disease is caused by mutations in the genes encoding type IV collagen, which is a major component of the basement membranes in the kidney, ears, and eyes. Therefore, the symptoms presented by the boy are consistent with Alport syndrome.

Final Answer: A.

question: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of slurred speech. The patient’s eldest daughter says that he couldn’t move his arm during the episode. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and a hemorrhagic stroke 6 years ago, which was treated surgically. After admission, the patient gets increasingly worse and loses consciousness. A noncontrast CT of the head shows a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient is taken to the operating room, where the SAH evacuated, and the vessel is repaired. Postoperatively, the patient is unresponsive. Several days later, a repeat CT of the head shows an enlarging aneurysm in a different vessel in the brain. The patient’s daughter is asked to consent to a non-emergent, life-saving operation since the patient is in a comatose state. She does not consent to the operation even though the physician stresses it would be life-saving. Upon further discussion, the physician finds out that the patient was abusive and neglectful to his children, and the daughter wants “to live in peace.” The patient has no written advanced directive. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

options.A: Follow the daughter’s wishes to withhold the operation
options.B: Refer this case to the court
options.C: Contact another family member for consent
options.E: Report the daughter to the police

model_answer: Final Answer: B

question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. She complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
model_answer:
The patient's presentation of hypertension, headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis, along with the laboratory findings of elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines, and serum epinephrine levels, suggest pheochromocytoma. The presence of diffuse thyromegaly along with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (anxiety, fine tremors, tachycardia, warm and moist skin) and the finding of hypercalcemia suggest hyperparathyroidism and thyroid medullary carcinoma. These three conditions - pheochromocytoma, hyperparathyroidism, and thyroid medullary carcinoma - are characteristic of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) 2A. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is MEN 2A.

Final Answer: C. Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A

question: A patient with a1-antitrypsin deficiency is warned by his physician that his increasing dyspnea may be worsened by his continued cigarette smoking. Which of the following factors, released by both neutrophils and alveolar macrophages, is responsible for the patient's condition?

options.B: Antibodies against alpha-3 segment of collagen IV (COL4A3)

model_answer:
α1-Antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that can cause lung damage, specifically emphysema, even in the absence of cigarette use. This is due to the fact that a deficiency of α1-Antitrypsin allows for increased elastase activity, which can destroy elastin in the alveolar walls of the lungs. Therefore, the factor responsible for the patient's condition is elastase.

Final Answer: E. Elastase

question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician due to sore throat and fever. He was in his usual state of health until 3 days ago when he began to complain of a sore throat as well as general malaise. The patient's past medical history reveals recurrent upper respiratory infections but no skin or soft tissue infections. The child had cardiac surgery as an infant but has otherwise been healthy. On presentation, his temperature is 100°F (37.8 °C), blood pressure is 115/72 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical exam shows white plaques on the tongue and mouth. A scraping of this material reveals a characteristic morphology after being treated with KOH. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a normal distribution of bands from this patient. Which of the following findings would most likely be found in this patient?

options.B: Delayed separation of the umbilical cord

model_answer:
None of the options provided seem to directly correlate with the symptoms and findings presented in the question. The symptoms described are indicative of a common oral yeast infection, often caused by Candida species, which is not directly associated with any of the conditions listed in the options. Therefore, I cannot provide a definitive answer based on the information given.

Final Answer: I don't know.

question: A 36-year-old man presents to his physician for a regular checkup, and he expresses an intent to quit smoking. He is a financial director with a 15-pack-year history of smoking who tried quitting several times. He tried different nicotine replacement products, none of which helped him. The patient has gastrointestinal reflux disease and takes omeprazole. The medical history is significant for a head trauma after which he had two seizure episodes. He does not have a history of any other disorders. Currently, he is not on any antiepileptic medication. He heard from his friend about an antidepressant that efficiently helps with smoking cessation. He would like to try this medication, and asks his physician for an advice. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the mentioned medication is correct?

options.A: Omeprazole interferes with bupropion metabolism and should be taken one hour prior to omeprazole consumption.
options.B: Bupropion is only effective when used together with nicotine replacement products.
options.C: Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.
options.D: The physician may prescribe bupropion for this patient only after a full cardiac workup is performed.
options.E: This patient has no contraindications for bupropion and may safely use it.

model_answer: Final Answer: C

question: The parents of a 16-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus present requesting information about the drug, exenatide, an injectable drug that only needs to be administered once a week. The patient’s blood glucose levels have been difficult to control on his current insulin regimen due to poor adherence to recommended therapy, and he has had difficulty putting on weight despite eating copiously. The patient is afebrile and his vital signs are within normal limits. His body mass index (BMI) is 19 kg/m2. Which of the following best describes why the patient should not be switched to exenatide?

options.A: Insulin production by the pancreas is insufficient for exenatide to be effective.
options.B: Exenatide suppresses glucagon secretion, which increases the risk of hypoglycemia.
options.C: Suppression of appetite makes it even harder for him to gain weight.
options.D: Exenatide is contraindicated in children below 18 years.
options.E: Gastric emptying is inhibited by exenatide.

model_answer: Final Answer: A.

question: A 52-year-old man with a history of gastric cancer that was treated with subtotal gastrectomy dies in a motor vehicle collision. At autopsy, examination of the spinal cord shows unilateral atrophy of the neurons in the area indicated by the arrow. Neurological examination of the patient when he was still alive would most likely have shown which of the following findings?

options.A: Decreased sense of temperature in the ipsilateral arm
options.B: Decreased strength of the contralateral leg
options.C: Decreased vibratory sense in the ipsilateral arm
options.D: Decreased positional sense in the ipsilateral leg
options.E: Decreased sense of crude touch in the contralateral arm

model_answer:
The context provided discusses various neurological signs and symptoms that can occur with different types of spinal cord lesions. Unilateral atrophy of neurons in the spinal cord would likely affect the nerve fibers on the same side (ipsilateral) of the body. The spinothalamic tract, which carries sensations of temperature and crude touch, crosses to the opposite side of the body within one to two segments of entering the spinal cord. Therefore, a lesion in this area would cause decreased sense of temperature and crude touch on the opposite (contralateral) side of the body. The other options (B, C, D, and E) are incorrect because they involve motor function, vibratory sense, positional sense, and crude touch, respectively, which are not primarily carried by the spinothalamic tract.

Final Answer: A. Decreased sense of temperature in the ipsilateral arm

question: A 3-month-old infant is brought to her pediatrician because she coughs and seems to have difficulty breathing while feeding. In addition, she seems to have less energy compared to other babies and appears listless throughout the day. She was born by cesarean section to a G1P1 woman with no prior medical history and had a normal APGAR score at birth. Her parents say that she has never been observed to turn blue. Physical exam reveals a high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the lower left sternal border. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is associated with which of the following abnormalities?
model_answer:
The infant's symptoms of coughing and difficulty breathing during feeding, decreased energy, and a holosystolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border suggest a congenital heart defect. The murmur described is characteristic of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common congenital heart defect. VSDs can occur as isolated defects or as part of a syndrome. The patient's symptoms do not suggest a syndrome, so the VSD is likely isolated. Isolated VSDs are usually sporadic, but can also be associated with maternal alcohol consumption, which is known to cause a variety of birth defects, including VSDs. 

Final Answer: D. Maternal alcohol consumption.

question: A 35-year-old woman presents with severe fear reactions to seeing dogs after moving into a new suburban neighborhood. She states that she has always had an irrational and excessive fear of dogs but has been able to avoid it for most of her life while living in the city. When she sees her neighbors walking their dogs outside, she is terrified and begins to feel short of breath. Recently, she has stopped picking up her children from the bus stop and no longer plays outside with her children in order to avoid seeing any dogs. Which of the following would be the best definitive treatment for this patient?
model_answer:
The patient's symptoms are consistent with a specific phobia, which is an excessive or irrational fear of a specific object, place, or situation that leads to avoidance behavior. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is the treatment of choice for specific phobias. CBT for specific phobias often involves exposure therapy, where the patient is gradually and repeatedly exposed to the feared object or situation in a controlled setting until the fear response is extinguished. Therefore, the best definitive treatment for this patient would be cognitive behavioral therapy.

Final Answer: D.

question: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and joint pain for the past 4 months. Examination shows erythema with scaling on both cheeks that spares the nasolabial folds and two 1-cm ulcers in the oral cavity. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
model_answer:
The patient's symptoms of fatigue, joint pain, facial rash that spares the nasolabial folds, and oral ulcers are suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. It is characterized by the production of autoantibodies, including antinuclear antibodies (ANA), anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA), and anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies. These autoantibodies form immune complexes with antigens, which can deposit in various tissues and cause inflammation. Complement proteins, including complement component 3 (C3), are consumed in the process of clearing these immune complexes. Therefore, patients with SLE often have low levels of complement proteins.

Final Answer: C. Increased complement component 3

question: Current recommendations state that a single hemoglobin A1c value of greater than 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. If this 6.5% cut-off is to be increased to 7.0%, which of the following would be true?

options.A: Increase in false negative test results
options.B: Increase in false positive test results
options.C: Decrease in true negative test results
options.D: Increase in true positive test results

model_answer:
Raising the cut-off value for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus from 6.5% to 7.0% would mean that fewer people would be diagnosed with diabetes. This would result in an increase in false negative results, as individuals who actually have diabetes (based on the original cut-off of 6.5%) would not be diagnosed under the new cut-off of 7.0%. 

Final Answer: A. Increase in false negative test results

question: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her concerned father. He states that ever since her uncomplicated delivery she has failed to gain weight, has had chronic diarrhea, and has had multiple bacterial and viral infections. During the course of the workup, an absent thymic shadow is noted and a lymph node biopsy demonstrates the absence of germinal centers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
model_answer:
The patient's failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, recurrent infections, absent thymic shadow, and absence of germinal centers on lymph node biopsy suggest a diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is characterized by a paucity of T cells and, often, B cells. The most common form of SCID is X-linked and due to a defect in the common gamma chain, a component of several interleukin receptors. However, another form of SCID is due to adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency. ADA is necessary for the breakdown of purines. Without it, deoxyadenosine accumulates and is toxic to lymphocytes. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a deficiency in adenosine deaminase.

Final Answer: C. Adenosine deaminase deficiency.

question: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of decreased appetite and abdominal pain for the last several weeks. Physical examination shows a well-appearing toddler with a palpable left-sided abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. A CT of the abdomen shows a large, necrotic tumor on the left kidney. Histological examination of the kidney mass shows primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli. This tissue is most likely derived from the same embryological structure as which of the following?
model_answer:
The described findings of a large, necrotic tumor on the left kidney in a young child, with histological examination showing primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli, are characteristic of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma). This is a malignancy of the kidney that typically occurs in children. The tumor arises from nephrogenic rests, which are remnants of primitive kidney tissue (metanephros). The metanephros gives rise to the definitive kidney and its collecting system. None of the options listed in A-E are derived from the metanephros. However, the closest related structure would be the adrenal medulla, as it is also a component of the urogenital system, which includes the kidneys. 

Final Answer: B. Adrenal medulla.

question: A 40-year-old man is referred to an optometrist. He complains of mild vision impairment over the last 6 months. His vision has continued to slowly deteriorate and his condition is now affecting his night driving. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled schizophrenia. He takes a low-potency typical antipsychotics and a multivitamin every day. He has been compliant with his medication and has regular follow-up visits. What is the best first step in the management of this patient’s symptoms?
model_answer:
The patient's symptoms of slowly progressive vision impairment, particularly affecting night driving, are concerning for a potential ocular pathology. Given that the patient is already seeing an optometrist, the best first step would be to conduct a thorough ocular examination. A slit-lamp examination is a common part of an ocular examination and can help identify a variety of eye conditions. Therefore, the best first step in the management of this patient's symptoms would be a slit-lamp examination.

Final Answer: E.

question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after losing consciousness at work. On presentation, she is found to be somnolent though she is able to be woken by vocal stimuli. She says that over the last 12 hours, she has been experiencing muscle spasms, blurred vision, dry mouth, and hallucinations. She says that the symptoms started after she went on a hike in the woods and foraged from plants along the way. Physical exam reveals dry red skin and enlarged pupils. Her bladder is also found to be completely full though she says she is unable to urinate. Which of the following drugs would most likely be administered to this patient to treat her symptoms?
model_answer:
The patient's symptoms of dry mouth, blurred vision, hallucinations, dry red skin, enlarged pupils, and urinary retention suggest anticholinergic toxicity, which can occur from ingestion of certain plants or medications. Anticholinergic toxicity can be remembered by the mnemonic "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, mad as a hatter, and full as a flask." Treatment involves discontinuation of the offending agent, supportive care, and in severe cases, administration of the antidote physostigmine, which is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the amount of acetylcholine available to compete with the anticholinergic agent at the receptor.

Final Answer: B. Physostigmine

question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fatigue and yellow discoloration of his skin. One week ago, he had an upper respiratory tract infection. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.4 g/dl and his mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 39% Hb/cell. A Coombs test is negative. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
model_answer: Final Answer: E. Splenic sequestration crisis

question: A 65-year-old man with a longstanding history of poorly-controlled hypertension and no recent illness or cardiac disease presents to clinic complaining of chest pain that is worse on inspiration and relieved by sitting forward. Vital signs are stable. On exam, you detect a friction rub. Routine labs show K 7.5 and Cr 5.1. If this patient's clinical signs and laboratory findings are indicative of a chronic condition, what would be expected on urinary analysis?
model_answer:
The patient's longstanding history of poorly-controlled hypertension, chest pain that is worse on inspiration and relieved by sitting forward, and the presence of a friction rub on exam are suggestive of pericarditis. However, the elevated potassium (K 7.5) and creatinine (Cr 5.1) levels are indicative of kidney dysfunction, likely chronic kidney disease (CKD) given the patient's history of hypertension. In CKD, the kidney's filtering units, the nephrons, are damaged and lose their ability to filter waste products and excess fluids from the blood effectively. This can result in the appearance of broad and waxy casts in the urine, which are indicative of severe, end-stage renal disease (ESRD). 

Final Answer: E. Broad and waxy casts

question: A 59-year-old man presents to his primary care provider with fatigue, a progressively worsening cough with flecks of blood, shortness of breath, and dark urine. He reports feeling ill for the past 3 weeks. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes chlorthalidone and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 20–30 cigarettes daily for the past 26 years. Anti-glomerular basement membrane serologies are positive. Which of the following is a specific feature for this patient’s condition?

options.E: Longitudinal splitting and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane

model_answer:
The patient's symptoms of hemoptysis (coughing up blood) and dark urine (indicative of hematuria), along with positive anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) serologies, suggest a diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome. This is an autoimmune disease characterized by circulating antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of type IV collagen, which is found in the basement membranes of the kidneys and lungs. This leads to a rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. On renal biopsy, linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence is seen due to the binding of anti-GBM antibodies along the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes.

Final Answer: D. Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence

question: A 51-year-old man presents the emergency room with chest pain. He mentions that the pain started several hours ago and radiates to his left neck and shoulder. He also mentions that he has some difficulty in breathing. He says that he has had similar chest pains before, but nothing seemed to be wrong at that time. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol during that episode and was prescribed medication. He also has a 3-year history of gastritis. The blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, respirations are 18/min, and the pulse is 110/min. He seems a little anxious. The physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities. An ECG shows slight changes in the leads. His physician talks to him about the benefits of taking low-dose aspirin daily. Which of the following would be a contraindication to the use of aspirin in this patient?
model_answer: Final Answer: C
